verses.text: The word of the LORD came to me, saying:
verses.comment: The prophetic introduction marks a direct revelation from God, reinforcing the authority of Ezekiel in receiving divine messages.

verses.text: Son of man, set your face against Mount Seir and prophesy against it.
verses.comment: Mount Seir represents Edom, the traditional enemy of Israel. Setting one's face implies an unwavering, determined prophetic stance.

verses.text: Say to it: Thus says the LORD God: Behold, I am against you, Mount Seir, and I will stretch out my hand against you and make you a desolation and a wasteland.
verses.comment: The outstretched hand of God often signifies judgment (see Exodus 6:6), showing His active intervention against injustice.

verses.text: I will lay your cities waste, and you shall become a desolation. Then you will know that I am the LORD.
verses.comment: Repeated throughout Ezekiel, the phrase 'you shall know that I am the LORD' reminds us that judgment reveals God's sovereignty and justice.

verses.text: Because you harbored eternal hatred and delivered the people of Israel over to the sword in the time of their calamity, in the time of the final punishment.
verses.comment: Edom's historical enmity and cooperation in Israel's downfall underline the seriousness of familial betrayal and how God judges nations for their actions toward His chosen people.

verses.text: Therefore, as I live, declares the LORD God, I will prepare bloodshed for you, and blood shall pursue you. Since you have not hated bloodshed, therefore blood shall pursue you.
verses.comment: God's oath, 'As I live,' expresses unchangeable resolve. The principle of divine retribution is stressed here—those who delight in violence reap its consequences.

verses.text: I will make Mount Seir a desolation and cut off from it all who come and go.
verses.comment: The complete isolation and destruction signify an enduring judgment, echoing themes of separation seen throughout Scripture.

verses.text: I will fill your mountains with your slain; those pierced by the sword shall fall on your hills, in your valleys, and in all your ravines.
verses.comment: This vivid imagery of devastation has both a literal and spiritual meaning, highlighting the weight of sin and the consequences of rejecting God's ways.

verses.text: I will make you a perpetual desolation, and your cities shall never be inhabited. Then you will know that I am the LORD.
verses.comment: The perpetuity of the punishment mirrors eternal consequences seen elsewhere, and brings to mind ideas of final judgment and the enduring justice of God.

verses.text: Because you said, 'These two nations and these two lands shall be mine, and we will possess them'—although the LORD was there—
verses.comment: This verse underscores God's presence among His people, prefiguring His desire to dwell with humanity. The enemy's claim echoes the temptation to grasp what belongs to God, reminiscent of the Fall.

verses.text: Therefore, as I live, declares the LORD God, I will act according to your anger and jealousy, which you showed out of your hatred against them. I will make myself known among them when I judge you.
verses.comment: Judgment reveals God's holiness and righteous standards, affirming the spiritual reality that the Lord will vindicate His people before all nations.

verses.text: You shall know that I am the LORD. I have heard all the blasphemies which you spoke against the mountains of Israel, saying, 'They have been laid desolate—they have been given to us to devour.'
verses.comment: God's attentive ear hears every word spoken against His holy people and land, revealing His intimate involvement in history and the importance of reverence.

verses.text: You magnified yourselves against Me with your mouth and multiplied your words against Me; I have heard it.
verses.comment: The pride and arrogance of Edom are noted by the Lord, suggesting God's special concern for humility and submission to His authority—qualities essential for deeper spiritual union with God.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD God: When the whole earth rejoices, I will make you desolate.
verses.comment: The contrast between joy for the world and desolation for the unrepentant enemy points to God's final restoration, which anticipates a future fulfillment in the gathering of all nations to Himself.

verses.text: As you rejoiced over the inheritance of the house of Israel because it was desolate, so I will treat you. You shall become desolation, Mount Seir, and all Edom—all of it. Then they will know that I am the LORD.
verses.comment: The inheritance of God's people is sacred, and Edom's rejoicing at their downfall earns divine judgment. The repeated promise 'then they will know that I am the LORD' reinforces the importance of recognizing God's supreme authority, a crucial step toward deeper unity in the faith as revealed throughout Christian history and tradition.
